title: Erdős Problem #423: Sums of Consecutive Terms Sequence
description: Let a₁=1, a₂=2. For k≥3, aₖ is the least integer > a_{k-1} that is a sum of at least two consecutive terms. What is the asymptotic behaviour? OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #423 from [Er77c, p.71] defines a greedy sequence where each new term must be a sum of at least two consecutive earlier terms. Credited to Hofstadter's inspiration from a similar Ulam-type question. Recent progress by Bolan and Tang (2024-2025) shows the excess a(n)-n is nondecreasing and unbounded, and infinitely many integers are missing from the sequence. OEIS A005243.
overview.problemStatement: Let a₁=1, a₂=2. For k≥3, aₖ is the least integer > a_{k-1} which is the sum of at least two consecutive terms a_i + a_{i+1} + ... + a_j for some i ≤ j < k. What is the asymptotic behaviour of this sequence? OPEN.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines the sequence (noncomputable), the consecutive sum property, initial values, growth properties (excess nondecreasing and unbounded), missing numbers (infinitely many), and asymptotic questions (convergence of a(n)/n, density). The known results theorem erdos_423_known is proved from axioms.
keyInsights: Each term is the smallest integer exceeding the previous that equals a sum of consecutive earlier terms
The sequence grows strictly faster than linearly: a(n) - n is unbounded (Bolan, Tang)
Infinitely many integers are missing, with 4 being the first
The asymptotic growth rate and density of the sequence are unknown

sections.title: Part I: The Sequence Definition
sections.summary: Defines consSeq: ℕ → ℕ with initial values 1, 2. Axiom: strict monotonicity.

sections.title: Part II: Consecutive Sum Property
sections.summary: Defines consecutiveSum and IsConsecutiveSum. Axioms: consSeq_is_consecutive_sum and consSeq_minimal.

sections.title: Part III: Known Initial Values
sections.summary: Axiom consSeq_values: first 8 terms (1,2,3,5,6,8,10,11). Axioms: verify_three, verify_five.

sections.title: Part IV: Growth Properties
sections.summary: Axioms: consSeq_lower_bound (a(n) ≥ n+1), excess_nondecreasing, excess_unbounded (Bolan, Tang).

sections.title: Part V: Missing Numbers
sections.summary: Defines seqRange and missingNumbers. Axioms: infinitely_many_missing, four_is_missing.

sections.title: Part VI: The Main Question
sections.summary: Defines ErdosQuestion423_convergence (a(n)/n → C) and ErdosQuestion423_density (density of sequence range).

sections.title: Part VII: Summary
sections.summary: Proved: erdos_423_known (combines nondecreasing excess and infinite missing), erdos_423_status (trivial). OPEN.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #423 asks about the asymptotic behaviour of a greedy sequence built from sums of consecutive terms. Recent progress shows the excess a(n)-n grows unboundedly and infinitely many integers are missing, but the precise growth rate remains open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would clarify the structure of greedy sequences defined by consecutive-sum constraints, connecting to additive combinatorics and the theory of Ulam-type sequences.
openQuestions: What is the asymptotic growth rate of a(n)?
Does a(n)/n converge? If so, to what constant?
What is the density of the set of integers appearing in the sequence?
How does this relate to the Ulam sequence (Problem #342)?
